title: Lendlease launches $270m off-the-plan retirement project in Brisbane
text:
Tony Randello, managing director of Lendlease Retirement Living, said interest among over-70s buyers had been strong so far, however many would prefer to wait until the development had been completed.

"We're selling well off the plan and buyers' interest has exceeded our expectations," he said.

The Bernborough Ascot is a part of the Brisbane Racing Club's $1.2 billion Master Plan.

"However, some retirees want to be able to touch and feel the home. The feedback we're getting is that they [buyers] remain interested but they want to come back and see it once it has been built.

"From experience, if we don't get the full sales off the plan before we complete, sales will arrive shortly after."

The trackside retirement community has been named after one of Australia's greatest thoroughbred racehorses, Queensland-born Bernborough, which won 15 consecutive races between 1941 to 1946.

Brisbane Racing Club chairman Neville Bell said Bernborough Ascot was a key pillar of the club’s $1.2 billion master plan to transform the Doomben and Eagle Farm precinct into a premier multigenerational lifestyle precinct for Brisbane.

"With construction of the first stage well advanced, we are delighted to see this project coming to life alongside the other residential, retail, commercial and community components of this exciting region," Mr Bell said.

"We expect many of our members will be very interested in the possibility of living at Bernborough Ascot, together with other longstanding locals from this area."

Lendlease owns and operates 72 retirement villages around Australia with about 17,000 residents.
description: Vertical community Bernborough Ascot will be built amid rising demand from retirees and Baby Boomers looking to downsize.
